I should clarify that I am not an author of that paper, although
it comes from the same research group.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> Once I got smarter than the e-mail and followed the whole link, I 
got to
> the PDF. 
> My reaction: 
> you taught networks to gamble? That's spectacular. I will 
certainly play
> with that 
> idea. I am already using penalties in my position controller 
project,
> but I had never 
> considered a scheme where the network itself scales the 'bet' to 
modify
> it's own 
> fitness scoring. That's a very elegant feedback system. 
> 
> chad 
> 
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> From: Kenneth Stanley
> Sent: 3/17/2004 8:21:04 AM
> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Multiple networks
> 
> Hi Chad, it sounds like a reasonable idea to me. A lot of the time 
> it's better to combine expertise than to go with only one method. 
> Actually, here is a paper on this subject from our research group:
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID
> (Pubs)=16
> 
> Note that this paper does not use NEAT as its neuroevolution 
method 
> (it came out around the time NEAT was first coming out), but it 
> still addresses the general idea of combining expertise and 
> expressing confidence. Of course, it would not work exactly the 
way 
> this paper says if you were to combine evolutionary and non-
> evolutionary approaches at the same time.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" wrote:
> > I've been thinking about using 'conflicting' networks/controllers
> > operating the same set of inputs and outputs. 
> > My thoughts revolve around a weighted summing device that 
recieves 
> both
> > the ouput and an associated confidence from each network, and 
the 
> output
> > of the system is a function of the confidence levels ( sudden 
rise 
> in
> > confidence having more meaning than a steady state confidence ) 
> and the
> > outputs of the functions.
> > This approach might allow for a coupling of seemingly 
incompatable
> > networks or controllers, such as a LSTM to recognize features in 
a
> > landscape, an evolved neural network for obsticle avoidence, and 
a
> > conventional controller for 'after-market' behaviour add-ons, 
with 
> out
> > re-evolving or re-teaching the previous networks.
> > The idea sounds like fun, except that I have no idea how to go 
> about
> > teaching anything how to describe how confident it is in its own 
> output.
> > Any thoughts?
> 
> 
> 
>
